Comment:
It's actually great that Indian investors are getting a reality check that high GMV and burn rates are not exactly the recipe for long term success, however I still see the same in #SharkTank.  Many investors are still lingering on #revenue model and blindly follow a B2C startup. It's still quite easy to go ahead and show a hyper delivery platform or a B2C e commerce product sales to get funding. 

We really need to understand if Indian investors moved, moving or thinking to move in a different investment world. 

Their confusion is actually killing the Indian Startup market , stifling the innovation, curbing the risk and basically pushing backwards. Even though the government is trying to be as supportive as possible.

Headline: ü¶à @SharkTank | Founded the first #VC in ME. Multi-exited founder | Building an ecosystem for a thriving humanity and planet. Co-GP to university, government & celebrity venture and PE funds. #ai #longevity #cleantech
Comment:
My podcast details the answer to this https://www.instagram.com/reel/DCKA55qtwPp/?igsh=MTB5cmI1MmsxbzQ0OQ==

Simply put - Historically, great businesses were built by creating a valuable product or service and selling it at a margin to create healthy sustainable growth. The flood of venture capital arguably disrupted this, shifting focus from sustainable business fundamentals to chasing valuations and funding rounds.

Perhaps the lifespan of companies is also an indicator of this reduced level of innovation and drive:
‚Ä¢	1965: Companies remained on the S&P 500 for an average of 32 years.  

	‚Ä¢	Forecast for 2028: Projections suggest that the average tenure will shrink to 12 years.
 
Whilst being well-funded isn‚Äôt inherently a problem, an overabundance of capital often leads to complacency, inefficiencies, and reduced innovation‚Äîultimately increasing the risk of failure. This reset in the market might just spark a return to real value creation, separating those driven by üí∏ from those genuinely committed to building game-changing products and services.

Headline: CEO | CFO | M&A | Growth Strategy | Early Stage Investor | Mentor
Comment:
The Indian venture capital industry went from reckless exuberance‚Äîblindly throwing cash at unsustainable, high-burn models‚Äîto an extreme conservatism that stifles innovation. First, it demanded ‚Äúscale or die,‚Äù pushing founders into unsustainable expansion. Now, it demands immediate profitability, starving even promising startups of capital. This pendulum swing exposes a lack of conviction and strategic thinking. True ecosystems are built on patient capital, not reactionary funding cycles. Investors must balance ambition with discipline, rather than oscillating between hype and fear. Otherwise, India risks losing its most innovative founders to markets that understand the long game.

#VC #Startups #India #FundingReset

This isn‚Äôt a funding winter, it‚Äôs a reality check wrapped in frost. The startups that mistook capital for strategy are feeling the chill, while the ones that treated money as fuel, not life support, will endure. There‚Äôs a lesson in Japan‚Äôs post-war economic rise, companies like Toyota and Sony didn‚Äôt just chase scale, they mastered efficiency, lean operations, and built products people actually wanted. The result? They thrived for decades, not just funding cycles.

I feel startups today need to think the same way. Valuations don‚Äôt build companies, resilience does.
